lessons.title: Mastering Keyframes
lessons.summary: Deep dive into creating, editing, and managing keyframes.

steps.title: What are Keyframes?
steps.body:
Keyframes are the foundation of animation in MotionKit. A keyframe captures the state of a property (position, rotation, opacity, scale) at a specific point in time.

MotionKit interpolates between keyframes to create smooth animations automatically.

steps.title: Adding Keyframes
steps.body:
There are two ways to add keyframes:

- **Record Mode** — Click the red Record button, then change any property in Figma. MotionKit captures the change at the current playhead position.
- **Manual** — Right-click a layer row in the timeline and choose **Add Keyframe** to insert one at the playhead.

steps.title: Editing Keyframes
steps.body:
Click a keyframe diamond to select it. You can:

- **Drag** it left/right to change its time
- **Shift+Click** to multi-select
- **Right-click** for options like Delete, Copy, Paste
- Use the **Curves** panel to edit its easing

Selected keyframes appear highlighted in blue.

steps.title: Discrete vs Smooth
steps.body:
By default keyframes interpolate smoothly. You can switch to **discrete** (step) interpolation for instant value changes — perfect for sprite-like toggling or visibility switches.

Right-click a keyframe and choose **Toggle Discrete** to switch modes.

lessons.title: Using Modifiers
lessons.summary: Loop, follow path, stroke trim — learn all modifier types.

steps.title: What are Modifiers?
steps.body:
Modifiers are effects that transform how an animation plays. They don't change your keyframes — they modify the output.

Open the **Modifiers** panel (wrench icon) in the sidebar to manage modifiers for the selected layer.

steps.title: Loop Modifier
steps.body:
The **Loop** modifier repeats the animation. Options:

- **Loop** — repeats endlessly
- **Ping-Pong** — plays forward then backward
- **Count** — set a specific number of repetitions

Great for loading spinners, breathing effects, and idle animations.

steps.title: Follow Path
steps.body:
The **Follow Path** modifier animates a layer along a vector path.

1. Select the layer to animate
2. Add a Follow Path modifier
3. Pick a vector path layer as the guide

The layer will travel along the path over the animation duration. You can control alignment, offset, and rotation behavior.

steps.title: Stroke Trim
steps.body:
The **Stroke Trim** modifier progressively reveals or hides a vector stroke.

Perfect for handwriting effects, line-draw animations, and path reveals.

- **Start/End** — control which portion of the stroke is visible
- **Offset** — shift the visible portion
- Works with any vector layer that has a stroke

lessons.title: Easing & Curves
lessons.summary: Master bezier curves and easing presets for natural motion.

steps.title: Why Easing Matters
steps.body:
Linear animations feel mechanical and robotic. **Easing** adds acceleration and deceleration to make motion feel natural.

Every keyframe transition has a bezier curve that controls its timing. The default is `ease-in-out` which starts slow, speeds up, then slows down.

steps.title: The Curve Editor
steps.body:
Select a keyframe, then open the **Curves** panel in the sidebar.

The bezier editor shows a graph where:
- **X axis** = time (left to right)
- **Y axis** = progress (bottom to top)

Drag the two control points to shape the curve. The preview updates in real-time.

steps.title: Easing Presets
steps.body:
Click **Show Presets** in the Curves panel to access built-in easings:

- **Ease In** — starts slow, ends fast (for exits)
- **Ease Out** — starts fast, ends slow (for entrances)
- **Ease In-Out** — smooth both ends
- **Spring** — overshoots then settles
- **Bounce** — bounces at the end

Click any preset to apply it instantly.

lessons.title: Exporting Animations
lessons.summary: Render your animations as MP4, GIF, WebM, or image sequences.

steps.title: Render Options
steps.body:
Click the **Render** button (or press `⌘E`) to open the export dialog.

Supported formats:

- **MP4** — Best quality, smallest file size. Ideal for demos and presentations.
- **GIF** — Universal support, larger files. Great for documentation and chat.
- **WebM** — Modern format, great compression. Perfect for web.
- **PNG Sequence** — Individual frames as PNGs. For post-production workflows.

steps.title: Quality & Performance
steps.body:
Higher resolutions and frame rates produce larger files but smoother playback.

- **1x** — matches your Figma frame size
- **2x** — retina quality, 4× file size
- **FPS** — 24 for cinematic, 30 for standard, 60 for smooth UI

GIFs are limited to 256 colors — use MP4 or WebM for gradients and photos.

steps.title: Work Area Export
steps.body:
Use the **Work Area** markers (`[` and `]` keys) to define a sub-range of your timeline.

When rendering, only the work area portion will be exported. This is useful for:

- Exporting a specific section of a long animation
- Testing short loops quickly
- Creating variations from the same timeline
